Albuquerque Public School officials say teachers will not be laid off despite a proposal to save money by hiring fewer teachers. , N.M. The Albuquerque Journal reports that APS officials say they’re trying to cover a projected $9.5 million shortfall in state funding. They expect to save $3.3 million by hiring fewer teachers in response to declining enrollment, but say they won’t remove any current teachers. The Albuquerque Journal reports Some schools might lose vice principals and other support staff who are hired based on formulas tied to enrollment, saving $1.2 million. APS Executive Director of Budget and Strategic Planning Debora Warren says enrollment may continue to decline this summer and administrators have to plan staffing levels now. She says the district will be more conservative than usual in estimating how many teachers are needed.
